Posts.Content: rocklizard wrote: I had microcalcs on the mammo and us, biopsy with Flat Epithelial Atypia (FEA) found, and just had a wire localization excision.  My results should be in any day now (though I can't bring myself to call the doc, like I don't really want to know.  That's kinda wussy.).  My question is, if it is just FEA, how often in the future am I going to get to go through this dance?  Do they have you going for mammo every 6 months, with biopsy and excision at the smallest sign of trouble?  I'm wondering if my life has changed, and gotten more tense, no matter what the results are.  For those that have gone through this several times, does it get easier (less out-of-my-mind worried) after the first time or two? Mar '12 odd mammo, microcalc on u/s, Mar '12 stereotactic biopsy FEA, Apr '12 wire-guided excision. Finding: fibrous breast changes, FEA. Slightly elevated risk for bc. Tamoxafin? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Question on Flat Epithelial Atypia and future screenings rocklizard stjohngirl

Posts.Content: rocklizard wrote: Now that I've had my biopsy and excision and no cancer was found, I have a follow up meeting with my surgeon on Friday.  I'm trying to think of all the things I want to ask her so I don't leave any out, and I'm hoping you guys will help. So far, I know I want a copy of the pathology roport from the excision. I want to ask what the FEA means for the future (higher risk? more biopsies and excisions in the future? more frequent or more detailed mammograms?). My mom swears she didn't take DES before I was born, but she had a miscarraige right before me and I had lots of reproductive problems (which can come from DES).  This would double my bc risk, and I want to know what she thinks of this.  The other thing I want to know is what does she think I should do to cut down on my future risk (something I had never taken nearly so seriously before!).  If I did and didn't do everything that was recommended I'd be a basket case, so I want to know what things have science or logic behind them.  I'm already considering giving up grilled meats, and that sucks because I love to grill and we have been eating grilled fish and chicken several times a week. Can you think of anything else I should talk to her about?  She is really good but incredibly busy so this is my shot at her.  Mar '12 odd mammo, microcalc on u/s, Mar '12 stereotactic biopsy FEA, Apr '12 wire-guided excision. Finding: fibrous breast changes, FEA. Slightly elevated risk for bc. Tamoxafin? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What to ask doctor on follow-up? rocklizard rocklizard

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 10:06PM rocklizard wrote: I like that - "what did I ever do to you?"  I definitely looks at my boobs differently now.  I'm still not sure if they're my friends or not. I'm sure your mom is worried for you, but there are some things I personally couldn't hear when I was in the wait.  One woman I work with started telling me about someone she knew who had bc and I had to stop her and tell her "I can't hear about this right now."  She started to go on to tell me more and I had to actually put up my hand and say "Honestly, you need to stop!  I am not in a place where I can hear this right now."  That got through and she totally changed the subject, and she's a nice person, but, wow.  It sounds like everyone around you is more emotional than you about it.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2012 03:15PM rocklizard wrote: Lynette73, thanks for the response.  Glad you're through the biopsy, now just the wait :-(  Do post any more hints if you think of them. I am curious how much tissue was removed, so I'll have to ask that.  I had almost no pain and I don't see a difference, so it couldn't have been much.  I know she didn't do any ducts, she would have said.
Posts.Title: What to ask doctor on follow-up? rocklizard rocklizard

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 11:29PM rocklizard wrote: Shachar,  I was in the waiting boat last week and it sucks.  Really sucks.  And the emotional roller coaster is continuous.  Everything was so intense, whether I was positive or negative, it was intense.  More intense than it had ever been.  I remember several "fog" days, which were almost a relief after the super high stress days, but the funk was hard.  It did make me realize again how important my family is to me.  I even told my husband, seriously, that if something happened to me I wanted him to remarry but it had to be someone who would love my daughter as her own.  Fortunately for him, he took me seriously at the time rather than making a joke out of it:-) I am sending you positive energy and hugs for this difficult time.  Elizabeth
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 11:56AM rocklizard wrote: carpediem, I've done the same thing with pictures.  I don't really like pictures of myself, but I knew that whatever happened I wanted there to be a lot of pictures with me in them, with my daughter and my husband.  It helped me to realize what an important part of their life I am.
Posts.Title: Still in shock Shachar grace56

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 01:11AM rocklizard wrote: jmack, I took my phone with me for work and told them I would be taking calls, even though they don't usually allow cell phones, and they were understanding (as I knew they would be).  You're much more patient than I was, which is probably a good thing.  I haven't ever been able to get docs to leave dx's on my voice mail, no matter how many times I tell them it's fine, but maybe yours will be different.  I hoping for good results from your procedure
Posts.Title: Biopsy results tomrw? 4/17 jmack rocklizard

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 07:10PM - edited Apr 12, 2012 07:19PM by rocklizard Shayne, I hope you are asleep right now and getting the energy you need for tomorrow.  The procedure will be over very soon, and the wait for results soon after that.  I did take my phone and CD player to the procedures and listened to the u-tube video and to a really good book on tape.  That helped. I understand exactly what you mean about knowing that your child is the most important thing in your life, the reason you do what you do.  My clarity, rising at my most awful time, was that what was most important in my life is my daughter (5yo), that I want to watch and help her grow up.  Everything else doesn't come close.  I had some really intense, serious conversations with my husband, and in one I told him that if something happened to me I wanted him to remarry, but only to someone who would love my daughter as their own beloved child.  It's amazing how the fluff burns at this time, and you see what is at your core. During my time in procedures and tests I took all the prayers and positive energy and good wishes I could get.  This time needs everything you can throw at it and more.    Know that I am thinking about you tonight and tomorrow, and wishing you an easy procedure and fast, happy results.  {{hugs}} Elizabeth
Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind Shayne rocklizard

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 10:51AM rocklizard wrote: Shayne, I am so glad things went well this time!  Yay!  Pat yourself on the back for getting through it so well.  I shook and cried at before mine as well and it turned out to be very easy.  I, too, felt better about drs and rns in after this whole ordeal, they were great.  I, too, was told by drs that things looked and felt good. I'm glad you felt me there with you because I was thinking about you.  Here in Oregon there's a fabulous foundation, Breast Friends, made up of people who've had breast cancer and who provide support for people going through it.  One of the women became my 'buddy' and called to check on me and even visited me in the hospital when I was in for the excision.  It was such an enormous gift and help to me.  I'm glad I could give some of that back. Know that I'm thinking about you and sending you good thoughts and serenity while you wait for your results.  Please let us know when you get them. Elizabeth

Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind Shayne rocklizard

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 05:58PM rocklizard wrote: Shayne, I'm so sorry you're going through this.  It seems you're feeling hopeless right now, just awful.  I'm hoping someone with more experience than me will chime in to help you through this. And, dang it, your husband needs to come home and be there with you.  Will he be home soon?  Have you posted on the DCIS board, or the newly diagnosed?  Someone there can speak from the other side of the diagnosis.  I hooked up with a group here called "Breast Friends" where there are volunteers who have been through breast cancer and they hooked me up with a volunteer who had the same surgeon I had and talked to me about her experience in great detail when I asked her to.  I'm not sure what kind of bc she had (sorry, I don't remember), but I know that was several years ago and it was really reassuring to hear how well she is doing now.  There may be something similar where you live. Several women on the board have mentioned that anti-anxiety drugs helped them get through the first while after being diagnosed.  You sound like me in that you get very anxious and I would be getting them right now.  I used them during the wait, and they helped.  For me, I do much, much better when I can keep the tension and stress down, and that's not easy for me. I hope you get a good sleep and are feeling better tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind Shayne rocklizard

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 12:22AM rocklizard wrote: I had one done last Wednesday.  Mine was for microcalc and flat atypical epithelial cells, not a lump, but it was a wire localization and excision.  My oncology surgeon, Johnson in Portland OR, operates in the afternoon (guess she likes it that way) so my surgery was at 3:30 pm.  I'd had a radioactive isotope image done two days before, and they'd seen something on the other breast (left one, surgery was on my right - news of that was NOT welcome) so I had to go in at 9 am so they could ultrasound that area before the surgery.  That way, if there was anything suspicious there she could biopsy/excise it at the same time.  Very effecient, these surgeons :-)  Actually, I wanted it all done at the same time if they had to.  Got there at 9 and they got me in my hospital gown.  The ones here have a place to plug in a tube like a hair-drier tube that heats up the whole gown.  Super spifferino and kept me really warm and cozy the whole time.  I had taken a Xanax at home because I am a stress biscuit big time.  They started an IV and I asked for a valium.  I had a really good book on tape so I listened to that.  I had also brought some meditations on my phone. I was most nervous about the wire localization because it sounded both painful and bizarre. At 11am they came to get me for the ultrasound of the left side and the wire localization (or, the wire-in-the-boob-procedure).  Ultrasound was simple.  Then the wire thingy.  I was super nervous, but the doc to do that was the same one who did my biopsy and that was almost painless (during and after) so that helped a bit.  They turned me almost on my side and I listened intently to my CD book.  I was waiting for the stinging of the lidocain and the feeling of the wire going in.  Honestly, I didn't feel either.  I could feel them over there doing something, and sometimes they pushed a bit on the breast, kind of like when hubby is getting really frisky, but that's it and then it was over.  The wire is really, really thin and they just taped the end above my breast.  They did an easy mammogram (no squeezing) to be sure the placement of the wire was good, then back to my room. Next waiting until 3:30 for the surgery.  Hubby read his SF book and I listened to my mystery and dozed (heated gown and warm blankets and xanax and 2 vallium).  I was expecting it to actually start after 3:30 since I'd heard that late surgeries usually do and that Johnsons was really thorough so often she was late.  But, at 3:30, she and OR nurse and anesthesiologist show up in the room, give a starter sedative, and hi-ho, to the OR where they put me right out (surgery was done under light anesthesia).  Woke up happy back in the room.  They gave me crackers and water and let me go home when I could go to the bathroom on my own and pee - took about 30 - 45 minutes.  Did find out the left side wasn't a problem when doc looked at the ultrasound, so only had the right side done. I had a Narco there, and one the next morning, but didn't really need them.  Since then I've taken 2 asperin occaisionally.  I went for a long walk the day after and felt fine.  Since I didn't have a lump, they may have taken out less than other women have had, but the excision was a breeze.  Now I have the waiting part, I should know by this coming Wednesday.  The surgeon had a good feeling about it, so I'm hopeful and not too stressed, but I'm also getting better (I think) at compartmentalizing and not thinking about it.  I was much more stressed after the needle biopsy. Good luck with your excision biopsy.  I'm hoping for an easy one for you, too, and b9 results for us both.
Posts.Title: Wire Localization/Biopsy Roxie1 sparkynfiesty

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 09:03PM - edited Apr 9, 2012 09:09PM by rocklizard Roxie, I'm really glad that my post helped you, even a little.  Sorry it was so long, I didn't realize until I looked back at it that it was a small book ;-) My doc gave me a prescription for Welbutrin too, but I ended up with celexa instead (on top of the xanax and ambian) because I haven't had Welbutrin before wasn't in a state to start something unknown.  I know exactly what you mean about feeling like you're coming out of your skin! I didn't need to take many of the drugs because I found a relaxation hypnosis video on line (if you're interested I can give you the link).  I watched it every night for days before and after my biopsy and it worked as well as the ambian.  And I got a massage and had a hypnosis session since that has worked for me before for medical anxiety. Do you know yet when your biopsy will be?

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 06:14AM rocklizard wrote: Shayne, you sound so much better, even at 3:30 in the morning.  I am glad.  It sounds like you have lots of support and you are doing all the things you need to do right now to help you get through this.  I can't believe you already have people with experience coming over for brunch tomorrow (today?) - how cool is that!  You are marshalling all your forces around you, getting your "team" surrounding you.  I think it's fabulous that you can have your sister come and help.  You have some resources that I couldn't duplicate and that sound amazing. I find that animals are very perceptive, amazingly so. My last dog knew when something was going on, but hated it when I was upset and would sit close by but not near me, whereas any other time he was right against me.    Sounds like the xanax worked for a while.  I used ambian or ambian CR at night for about a week.  I didn't need the drugs long term, but I did right at first. I'm glad your husband is coming home!  I think this is a good time to be selfish and ask for what you need. Know that you're in my thoughts.

Posts.Title: Scared out of my mind Shayne rocklizard

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 09:49AM - edited Apr 11, 2012 09:58AM by rocklizard Hi Shayne.  I'm so sorry you are going through this and I completely understand the crushing worry that goes with it  I can't imagine that not happening. I too was totally scared of just the procedure, with the results being an extra worry. I'm sending you positive energy and hugs and my wishes for b9 results. I had microcalcs on my mamm and u/s.  The floor dropped out from under me at that moment.  I was told I needed to have a stereotactic biopsy  I am the wimpiest of the wimps when it comes to medical stuff, and took xanax for several days before and the morning of.  When I got there, they saw my face and told me to take another xanax :-)  Then they did the procedure and I barely felt anything.  I've had hangnails that have hurt worse, both the during and the after.  I did have an excellent doctor do it, which probably helped.  Waiting afterwards for results 2 days later was excruciating.  I don't remember that much about the procedure, other than lying on a table with my boob hanging down.  Nothing hurt, maybe a small prick of a needle.  It was really fast. They did find FEA (80% chance it would be nothing) in the biopsy (even just the word "biopsy" is ugly and scary), but an excision later showed it all b9 (90% chance of that).  Even the excision was easy, except for my worrying.  Your chances are excellent that it won't be any problem and all will be b9 in the biopsy.  They are just being extra careful and they can find so much more in mammo and u/s than they used to be able to. During my waiting time I did take some anxiety meds, but I also found a great self-hypnosis video on u-tube (I can send you a message with the link if you want, or it's in the thread Roxie1 started), got a massage,  had some hypnosis, had my naturopath give me some herbal anxiety remedies, and those things helped a lot.  And I began to think of the team of doctors as a "team", working together to help me get through this, and that helped me, too. And this board was a god-send, just an amazing gathering place and resource. Elizabeth
